title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Did Respondent make the constitutional arguments below?
answer_text: I believe it was included in a small portion of their -- Appellee's brief below, Your Honor.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review your case, is there any portion of activity that we're talking about that was done at the direction of the military that's involved here?
answer_text: We don't think so, Your Honor, and the reason is supervision and escorting were left entirely to Fluor under the contract. Once the bomber was hired and -- and was on the base, it was up to Fluor under its contractual obligations to supervise him at his worksite, as well as to escort him.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And would you spend just a brief moment discussing why Boyle is not dispositive or why it doesn't control here?
answer_text: Sure. So Boyle is all about a contractor who does what the government says. That is the heart and soul of Boyle.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: What do you do with the entire text and history of the Constitution, which says war-making, war-fighting in combat zones is a federal interest, and the states, Article I, Section 10, and otherwise, have nothing to do with how America conducts its operations in a combat zone?
answer_text: Certainly, Your Honor. So Articles I and II do not automatically preempt state law when it comes to federal contractors, and we know that from cases like Penn Dairies and North Dakota. In Penn Dairies, this Court said there is no clause of the Constitution which purports, unaided by congressional enactment, to prohibit such regulations.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: But can Texas regulate how the military structures its operations at Bagram, or can South Carolina regulate it? And, you know, that raises another question here which is pointed out by Judge Silberman in his opinion on this, which you're familiar with, which is can 50 different jurisdictions regulate what's going on at Bagram?
answer_text: Certainly, I'll address in turn. So, as to the constitutional structural point, we know the default is common law claims Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, I -- I agree with that, so I don't want this to sound like I disagree with that. Congress can certainly act. The question is, what's the baseline?
answer_text: So -- so the baseline

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Counsel, isn't the simple answer to Judge Kavanaugh is the 50 states can't tell the military what to do, correct?
answer_text: Certainly, absolutely correct, Your Honor.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: -- that absent a conflict, an entire field is preempted. And what you're saying, I think, by using Little and Mitchell, is that an entire field in our history has not been considered preempted, correct?
answer_text: That -- that is correct, Your Honor.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: All right. So now let's go down to something more, I think. The interest that's being protected is military interests, correct?
answer_text: Yes.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And so, if there's no conflict, there's no interest to protect, correct?
answer_text: There's nothing here Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: That's the question that Justice Thomas asked you, which is there has been no directive by the state that the contractor had to do X, Y, and Z. It was a -- it was a directive of the military, correct?
answer_text: Correct, Your Honor. I mean, so we -- we think that the state -- state law duty also applies here, the duty of reasonable supervision.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: If the government directed unreasonable conduct, there would be no liability, correct?
answer_text: Correct. The government did not direct Fluor to disregard supervision duties.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review doesn't extend to independent contractors, you might say, well, it makes sense to allow liability to remain even if we're doing it as a matter of federal common law, right?
answer_text: That -- that -- that is certainly correct, Your Honor. So there is a line of cases that say, as a federal -- as a matter of federal common law rule, we're going to adopt a state law rule here. But I think the simplest way here is to just -- just read Boyle as it is, and it's about a contractor who does what the government says.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Do you understand
answer_text: Mr. Chang

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: Yeah, sure.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Do you understand Boyle then to create a very narrow kind of preemption that's not constitutional, that really is just about the conflict of conflict terms -- sorry, contract terms?
answer_text: Yes, that's how we understand it. And that -- and that's what the opinion in Boyle said as well because Boyle carves out two hypotheticals where you're dealing with a government contractor.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: But what I got from your brief was you want us to, you know, limit it as much as possible. Did I read too much into your brief?
answer_text: No. So our position is that this Court does not have to overrule Boyle because we win even under Boyle's terms. And, certainly, the only reason that this Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, was Boyle correctly decided? Suppose it was before us today. What would you say?
answer_text: I would follow what you wrote in Garcia, Your Honor, that the Supremacy Clause is limited to the Constitution and federal statutes and treaties.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: -- that's something else. I mean, what I took from your brief is you're saying Boyle's inconsistent with textualism. Who wrote Boyle?
answer_text: Justice Scalia wrote it.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, do you -- are you willing to -- are there situations in which the -- the Supremacy Clause itself has a preemptive effect?
answer_text: This Court has understood it so, and in -- as this Court said in United States versus Washington, there are circumstances where the state law directly regulates the federal government or it discriminates against the federal government or its contractors.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So why wouldn't that apply when what is at issue are actions taken by a military contractor basically on the battlefield, and you want state courts and state juries to decide whether what the military contractor did is justified?
answer_text: No, Your Honor. First, we're dealing with something that occurred on a civilian part of the base

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: -- it -- it -- yeah, it's a military base in a war zone. And the very fact that there was this terrorist attack there shows a connection with the conduct of the war, doesn't it?
answer_text: So we're dealing with something that the Army left entirely to Fluor to do. And this is a natural consequence of the fact that Congress knew about contractor liability but has not limited -- limited servicemembers to be able to sue contractors when they're injured.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: I mean, suppose a contractor said -- a contract says that the contractor is to provide appropriate suit appropriate protection when it is accompanying a convoy through a dangerous area, all right? answer_text: It depends on what the Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: I think -- I think Boyle contemplates litigation over that issue.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Seriously?
answer_text: But, on

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: What would you think of a rule like that?
answer_text: I -- we -- we would certainly be okay with that rule. Certainly, if the Court is already thinking about creating some sort of a federal common law rule in this area, we think it should be the one that furthers the government's interests by avoiding contractor negligence and -- and incentivizes contractor adherence in a -- in a war zone. And this is -- this ended up injuring multiple U.S. soldiers on the base because Fluor didn't do what the Army told it to do.

title: 24-924_2c8f

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So, if that -- seriously?

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Doesn't that seem like a pretty big problem for your theory if that's the state law if -- or if the default is whatever law would otherwise apply, as Justice Kavanaugh is saying, the enemy's law is going to apply to the -- I mean, that suggests that maybe a federal common law should apply, maybe not the common law rule that Fluor and the government want, but if the alternative is a default to Afghan law?
answer_text: So -- so two responses to that, Your Honor. The first is that -- so, when it comes to applying foreign law to judge Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: We believe it's -- it's a branch of federal common law preemption, Your Honor, so

answer_text: So -- so what I was talking to Justice Alito about was cases like U.S. v. Washington and Penn Dairies and North Dakota

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: There is a difference, Your Honor.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: What is the difference?
answer_text: The difference -- the difference is one -- one comes from the structure of the Constitution and -- and this Court's decisions.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And is it your view that Boyle comes out differently under Justice Kavanaugh's theory? I mean, I guess I'm trying to understand that if we sweep as broadly as this is a war zone and there's a uniquely federal interest, I -- I thought that was also the case, not maybe the war zone part but the uniquely federal interest part, in Boyle. So doesn't it come out differently?
answer_text: Your Honor, there is certainly a tension

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: -- if -- if -- if we could just say at step 1 uniquely federal interest and that's the end of it, right?
answer_text: That is not even the analysis in Boyle. Boyle -- uniquely federal interests was a starting point in Boyle. Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: -- say a little about the Badilla test? As I read your brief, in the last few pages, you seemed to say that if the Court applies the kind of Boyle analysis here, it's the Badilla test that you would suggest. Why -- why is that?
answer_text: So -- so we think that the Badilla test is more faithful to -- to what this Court's teaching in Boyle. Again, Boyle zeroed in on the federal government's interest in getting its work done and making sure that there wasn't a conflict between that decision Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: If preemption depends on the interpretation of a contract and whether the contractor violated the terms of the contract, do you want us to adopt something like the -- the rule that used to apply in foreign sovereign immunities cases so that if the government says there was no violation of the contract, that's the end of the matter? Would you say no, the plaintiff still has the opportunity to litigate that issue in state court, presumably, possibly in front of a jury?
answer_text: We don't have a strong position on that, Your Honor. Certainly, if the Court says what the military says is preclusive, that's good for us because the military favored us in this case.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review it would be preclusive against Fluor. Would it be preclusive against you on the issue of preemption?
answer_text: Like I said, we don't have a position one way or another on that.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: How can you not have a position on that? That seems to me quite critical to what's at stake here.
answer_text: Certain -- certainly, Boyle at step 1 leaves that possibility open in this area. It anticipates litigation over what the specification meant and whether there was a compliance with that specification. It would be a really hard case for any plaintiff to disagree with an army coming in.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: As I understand your Heritage Reporting Corporation

As I understood it, it was that as the Fourth Circuit said, the combatant activity activities exception has a policy of -- of protecting the military's judgment, and that meant that even the imposition per se of state law was -- was a problematic imposition.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Justice Alito? Justice Sotomayor?
answer_text: No.

title: 24-924_2c8f

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: That would be non-discriminatory, but, again, that might conflict with the provision of

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: No, because the DBA already precludes things like that.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: If -- if it was, like, a safety regulation, like here, that could certainly be it.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: Subject to Final Review that's going to be a lot of finger-pointing on that. And the retired military officers say, in military theaters, legal uncertainty and finger-pointing are an invitation to ruin. And I'm just curious your response to that.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, the military found that, right?
answer_text: Oh, certainly. I mean, so

title: 24-924_2c8f

You know, that would be an interesting discussion, I'm sure. Do you envision that kind of testimony happening in the state court?
answer_text: No, not at all because, here, the Fourth Circuit already agreed with us that the litigation here would not lead to assigning fault to the military. We can -- we can assume the military made decisions that it made and we can judge Fluor's actions under -- under those military decisions as a given. We can take that as a given.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Have any federal courts gone your way on this -- on this general issue so far?
answer_text: So the Badilla -- Badilla court has agreed with us, and that's why there was a circuit split in this case.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Just to follow up quickly on Justice Kavanaugh's question about the finger-pointing and the kinds of questions that the United States would be asked, it's my understanding in the United States' brief that it said that it could assert the state secrets privilege and reserve the right to do so, although it had not yet in this case, right?
answer_text: That's correct.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So, if there was confidential information, there would be, you would agree, some sort of protection?
answer_text: A hundred percent. And and the reason why -- and the fact that there are other mechanisms to protect the government's interests like that undercuts the need to displace state law with federal common law in this case.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: That -- that's correct. I mean, if we're creating a federal rule to further the government's interests, the violations have to be factored in too.

title: 24-924_2c8f

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: Not at all.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So Congress did not envision a world necessarily in which contractors would not be held liable for these kinds of things?
answer_text: Not at all. And that Congress doubled down in the Westfall Act when it passed Westfall Act to protect federal officials from lawsuits. It adopted the definition of the FTCA, which is the same excluding contractors.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review further proceedings under that test? That was not what was applied here, correct?
answer_text: No. But you should not there's no need to, Your Honor, because we made arguments about why our position is correct under the Badilla test. It has not been disputed that they could -- Fluor could somehow meet that test here.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Are all contractors immune from suit on military bases?
answer_text: No. We would agree with the test that the -- that the government has proposed here, and to establish preemption here, you would have to show that the injuries and the claims arose out of combatant activities and that the contractor was acting within the scope of its contracts.

title: 24-924_2c8f

Why isn't that a judgment that really cries out for congressional decision and -- and what -- what expertise do we have in setting that rule?
answer_text: So, on that point, I would say this Court doesn't have expertise, and it said that in a number of cases, in determining what would best serve the military's interests on the battlefield. But this gets back, I think, to Justice Kavanaugh's

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So why not just apply Boyle and be done with it?
answer_text: Because what we have at issue here is the uniquely federal interest of the federal government's exclusive power to wage war. That was not what the Court addressed in Boyle. And I think -- you know, I think what is notable

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review question. We have to decide how important is it for the military to have contractors not fearful of liability versus how is it important is it for the military to have contractors who don't injure military members? Right?
answer_text: That's a -- that is a -- that is what you're asking us to -- to weigh, and you're asking us to come down on one side rather than the other. And I'm just suggesting to you there are really good arguments on both sides of this which would advance the war -- war-making function of the federal government, and I don't know.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: Yeah.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: It would -- we would consider it preemption. That would be the

answer_text: But, in the absence of congressional action, yes, we would say a state law claim or a tort -- a tort claim would not be allowed to proceed.

title: 24-924_2c8f

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: It's -- you can look to the Constitution, and I -- I think this should be an easier case for determining a uniquely federal interest. The Constitution vests the war powers in the federal government and expressly states that states may not engage in Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Can -- is Mr. Hencely's suit a tort suit or a contract suit?
answer_text: He brought both claims. The remaining claims are tort claims. For his breach-of-contract claim, that was dismissed because he's not a third-party beneficiary to Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So is it -- would it be odd to have a rule in which the scope of preemption for a tort suit depends upon whether or not there was a breach of a contract as to which he was not a third-party beneficiary?
answer_text: Yes. Yes. That would be very strange in my view.

title: 24-924_2c8f

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: No. They haven't attempted to, but I think they probably would not be able to. That would be left to the Court.

title: 24-924_2c8f

answer_text: There's no -- there's really no legislative history about that. The fact that it was adopted shortly after World War II to address combatant activities in time of war would suggest that they had the -- had that in mind.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: There could be the situation where the military says: There was no breach, the contractor says there was not a breach. So wouldn't the rule that we adopt have to deal with all three of those situations?
answer_text: I think it would. And I think what's critical here is we are clearly in the situation where there is a disagreement between Fluor and the government about whether there was a breach. title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And then the military runs a 5K, right, and -- and anyone who's run a 5K, there are lots of people stacked together at the starting line, right?
answer_text: And there was a lot and just, by the way, there's a lot of disagreement about what it meant that Fluor's duty to supervise. Our position was that it was our duty to supervise to ensure that the employees carried out the work that they were supposed to do to fulfill the obligations under the contract, not to provide security, not to provide force protection. That remained the military's responsibility.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: When did you learn -- don't tell me what you shouldn't at this point obviously. When did you learn that he was a member of the Taliban or former member of the Taliban?
answer_text: It was certainly after the attack. And I'm not sure. It was likely when, you know, the AR 15-6 report came out or maybe in the course of the investigation.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: But you could still have terrorist attacks. You could have -- so how is a court supposed to decide when your proposed exception would apply?
answer_text: So, under the test that we've supported and the government has Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: These are injuries from an enemy attack, right?
answer_text: But that's surely pretty broad. I mean, Justice Thomas was asking you about, you know, the food services and an E. coli outbreak. I mean, supporting the military's activities, I mean, that is pretty broad, and it seems to me that if you want courts to look at the combatant activities Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review exception from the Federal Tort Claims Act, we're right back to this question of is what you're really asking for a virtual extension of the text of that exception?
answer_text: So I would -- the -- the hypothetical I got was E. coli on Bagram, and I would say yes, you may -- it may be a different conclusion, E. coli in San Diego or at a base to troops that aren't ready to deploy. It's not -- every base is not looked at the same. The actual injury is examined to determine its connection to combat activities, which is not viewed as everything the military does.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Would be.
answer_text: -- because of the way it Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So it could potentially extend to domestic activities if they were supporting the combatant activities abroad?
answer_text: It could.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: You don't need to say anything more. And just finally, do you see yourself as standing completely united with the government's understanding of the rule, or do you see any differences between your position and the government's?
answer_text: We -- we support the government's position. The way it played out, some of the courts of appeals have adopted a slightly different rule than the government, but there's not a lot of daylight between those rules, and we see benefits in the -- in the government's rule.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And just to clarify, you -- your rule is tantamount to a field preemption kind of concept. I think you accepted that, is that right? That's what you're seeking essentially?
answer_text: So, certainly, with respect to claims on a foreign battlefield, I think you would view it as field preemption. And that's largely because applying conflict preemptions, we just think there's an inherent conflict between duties of reasonable care under state tort law and what the military demands and needs on a battlefield in combat operations.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Could you define, beyond the combat situation -- scenario, what you mean by "uniquely federal interests"? Heritage Reporting Corporation
answer_text: Subject to Final Review

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, I'm grant let's say I grant you the combat. Beyond that, how -- how do we define it?
answer_text: Well

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review why don't -- why isn't that unique?
answer_text: Well, I -- I think that there, the states would have more interest in what's going on in California than they do in what's going on in Bagram. But we're not asking the Court to invent a new type of -- of preemption here. We think that when Boyle talked about uniquely federal interests, that's a concept that this Court used in Sabbatino to say the active state doctrine is an area of uniquely federal interest.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review battlefield because it's not as directly engaged as Bagram was in this case?
answer_text: Well, the rule that we're asking for would talk about whether there are combatant activities, and we're using the exception in the FTCA as a model. And just as the Court did in Boyle, it used a different exception. It was looking at general procurement contracting and so it was looking at the discretionary function exception.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review the E. coli infection takes place, you know, 700 miles away in a base that is supporting the activities at Bagram?
answer_text: I -- I think that if if -- that that's going to be a question about what's -- what -- what it means to arise from the military's combatant's activities. And we -- we also have the second prong, which is about -- and -- and just to finish the answer to the first prong, that can certainly extend to people who are supplying the troops, who are on the very front lines.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review the troops. What about about preparing the rations of food that is going to eventually be used at Bagram and there's some, you know, infection at the food plant in, you know, I don't know, someplace in the United States?
answer_text: Yeah. I -- I think that -- I'm not sure how the combatant activities exception in the FTCA has been construed in a context like that. I think that for preemption purposes here, this goes to a question that Justice Barrett just asked whether this really needs to be overseas.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Why it is that state liability would be so injurious to the government's interests in that context, which is, I thought, the context that we're concerned about in this very case.
answer_text: That -- that's right.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Why? Because it changes the relationship between the parties. It alters the behavior of the contractors on the ground.
answer_text: They are less willing to do risky things. They may indulge in a "mother, may I" dynamic where they have to keep asking for permission, hey, you want me to do something pretty dangerous, can you please confirm for me, sign in triplicate that you have to do it this way. And I -- I want you to be aware that that's really dangerous because I want it on Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Wouldn't that answer apply just as well to Boyle?
answer_text: It would apply just as well to Boyle. Part of the difference, though, is that Boyle was talking about general procurement activities for the government writ whole. It happened to arise in the context of a military contract.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And is it a good idea to adopt a rule that would put the government to the choice about invoking this privilege, which in my understanding is used very infrequently on a regular basis?
answer_text: You're -- you're correct that it's used infrequently. And the national security concerns that are at interest, that that are served by the -- by the state secrets Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, isn't there a greater risk of death or serious injury as a result of an alleged breach of contract in a war zone as opposed to an alleged breach of contract outside of a war zone?
answer_text: Well

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review doesn't -- isn't there a greater potential interference with the interests of the federal government with respect to the first?
answer_text: Yes. And -- and this is a point that the D.C. Circuit made in the Saleh opinion, where it talked about the idea of tort laws requiring non-risky behavior all the time isn't compatible with -- with a war zone.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Justice Sotomayor?
answer_text: No.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Justice Kagan? Justice Kavanaugh?
answer_text: A couple things just to clarify. Uniquely federal interest branch of preemption is a separate doctrine from Boyle, Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Subject to Final Review right, or a preexisting doctrine, a preexisting doctrine?
answer_text: Yes. It predates Boyle. The Court has continued to recognize it as being appropriate.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: On the field conflict terminology, I want to get your understanding of what counsel said, which is my understanding is he said, when there's an inherent conflict in a particular kind of area, you can call that "field," and Garamendi Footnote 11 and other cases in the Court's jurisprudence have essentially said that. Is that your understanding, or do you have a slightly different understanding?
answer_text: In our brief, we said we think you could think of this in either way. But, if you had to pick, I think I would say that it's a form of field preemption, and I Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: "Hostile" might be too strong a word, but a state that, you know, has laws that it's trying to impose different obligations on the United States' conduct of war than the United States itself is trying to impose?
answer_text: Yeah. I -- I think that my friend already conceded that that would probably fall because it's a discrimination against the government and it's treating the government differently.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: You're not concerned about that?
answer_text: I -- I mean, I -- I'm not concerned if you adopt our rule, which would Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: If we adopt their rule, are you worried about the state that's not supportive?
answer_text: Yes, we are concerned that -- that -- I mean, as I said, we're worried either way. We think that the imposition of the threat, the specter of tort liability is affecting the relationship between the government and its contractors in a war zone, and we don't want that interference to begin with.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: And what about the Afghan law, so the state choice-of-law rules lead to Afghan law being applied in a suit like this and -- and who knows what that leads to? Do you have a concern about that, or is that not a concern?
answer_text: That -- that is a concern. And I think that -- I'm not exactly sure what -- what the parties' answers to that -- answer to that question really is Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Well, some courts have applied Iraqi law or other foreign law in these kinds of situations, correct?
answer_text: I don't know about combatant activities situations. And there may be public policy reasons not to apply foreign law in certain instances. That's really a conflict-of-laws choice-of-law question.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: So there's been a lot of hypothesizing about what might happen if this kind of tort liability is allowed to take place, but my understanding is that right now, only a few states limit liability, and so the background is that we have the rule operating where these kinds of lawsuits can be brought. Am I wrong about that?
answer_text: Well, I mean, there have been several suits. Several of them have been -- have -- have been rejected on the grounds that -- that -- that there -- there hadn't been a violation of the contract or

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Have all the -- the policy concerns that you have articulated, have they been happening, the finger-pointing and the increased prices and the other problems?
answer_text: Well, I -- I -- I don't know about the -- the -- we don't have data on increased prices because I -- I -- I just don't think that -- that -- that we have enough of an effect there. These -- these are very large contracts that we've had in Afghanistan and Iraq. There are a handful of companies that that successfully competed for them.

title: 24-924_2c8f
question_text: Thank you, counsel. Rebuttal, Mr. Chang?
